More Madame Alexander than Bridgerton, but all that‚Äôs changed with modern interpretations of the iconic fall hue. ‚ÄúThis trend is something I‚Äôve been playing with for a few years now, and it‚Äôs been growing within the editorial makeup world ‚Äî it has now developed into a mainstream trend,‚Äù Sephora beauty director David Razzano tells Refinery29. ‚ÄúThe initial inspiration for using burgundy again was a reference to authentic post-punk ‚Äô80s goth makeup styles. That subculture is clearly a defining moment that is being referenced heavily in editorial work as well as runways.‚Äù¬† Just as the dark red hue swept fall runways this past season, burgundy has been slowly taking over makeup launches ‚Äî¬†and not just in the realms of lip and cheek products, but notably in eye makeup form: Bordeaux eyeliners, mascaras, and more have been trending among brands like Rare Beauty, Patrick Ta, and Kosas. ‚ÄúBurgundy is a very flattering shade on almost all skin tones and eye colors making it the perfect eye and complexion enhancer,‚Äù makeup educator (and TikTok beauty guru) Rose Siard tells Refinery29. Ready to rock some red? Keep reading for a deep dive on how to try the trend (and the key products to get you there). DashDividers_1_500x100 Eyes View this post on Instagram A post shared by steph huiü¶ã (@stxph.h) Rich, luminous jewel tones on eyes are always a fall mood,¬†and burgundy on eyes is an evolution of warm terracotta tones from years past. (I personally love a thin band of dark red eyeliner on my upper lashline ‚Äî it makes my dark brown eyes glow.) ‚ÄúStarting small with your waterline is the perfect way to incorporate [burgundy] into your everyday routine,‚Äù says Siard. ‚ÄúBoth your eye color and complexion are factors when it comes to this color family. If you are fair to light, the Kosas Soulgazer Intensifying Waterproof Gel Eyeliner in Bewitch would be a great starting point, and for deeper skin tones, try the Lanc√¥me Le Stylo Eyeliner Pencil in Ruby Fever,‚Äù explains Razzano. Ready to turn things up? ‚ÄúFor a bold eye, use Danessa Myricks Beauty: ColorFix Multi-Use Eye, Cheek & Lip Waterproof Liquid Pigment in shade Vamp, creating an intense smokey eye,‚Äù he adds. ‚ÄúFinish off the look with a few coats of mascara.‚Äù (Bonus: Danessa Myricks‚Äô ColorFix pigments can also be worn on lips and cheeks ‚Äî¬†and pro tip: A little goes a very long way.) DashDividers_1_500x100 Lips View this post on Instagram A post shared by FENTY BEAUTY BY RIHANNA (@fentybeauty) Perhaps the most traditional take on this trend is in the lip category, where brick red hues have long been a popular choice for the fall and holiday seasons; however, the modern interpretation is less prim and more punk. ‚ÄúI love pairing a lip like Sephora Collection Cream Lip Stain 10HR Liquid Lipstick in Red Desert with a soft smokey eye in light grey tones like those in the Makeup By Mario: Master Mattes Eyeshadow Palette in The Neutrals, to create a beautiful, chic look,‚Äù says Razzano.¬†¬† Refinery29 contributing writer and beauty journalist Humeara Mohamed is equally as enamored with burgundy: ‚ÄúI think moody, burgundy-toned lips look beautiful on light and darker skin tones alike, which makes it feel quite wearable and less daunting than other statement tones. You can also smudge out a burgundy hue to look a little more lived-in and less ‚Äònight out‚Äô. After years of the clean girl aesthetic and its subtle glossy lips, burgundy is the antidote to forced, fake perfectionism. It allows us to experiment and have fun with our makeup again.‚Äù DashDividers_1_500x100 Face View this post on Instagram A post shared by JO BAKER (@missjobaker) Hot blush summer has given way to cozy blush fall, so don‚Äôt be afraid to swap rosy tones in favor for a darker, plummy red. (I love dotting a stain on the apples of my cheeks that makes it look like I‚Äôve just come in from the cold.) ‚ÄúA great and easy way to create a beautiful, simple, monochromatic burgundy look is to use Milk Makeup: Lip + Cheek Cream Blush Stick in shade Muse and softly create a stained cheek and lip look,‚Äù says Razzano. Cream formulas tend to be a little more forgiving in terms of color payoff, but if you‚Äôre ready for a dramatic, flushed look, don‚Äôt hesitate to try a powder version like NYX Buttermelt Blush in Back and Butta (a favorite of Siard‚Äôs). title: Antiperspirant vs. Deodorant: What's the Difference?
description: Deodorant and antiperspirant - it's the same thing, right? Most people use the two words interchangeably, but there are actually some key differences between the products. It's easy to mistake the two, especially when drugstores and beauty retailers have a slew of options packaged similarly, but knowing the difference between deodorant and antiperspirant can help you find the right product for your needs. Simply put, one helps mask the smell of sweat while the other prevents sweat and body odor. The choice may appear obvious, but everyone's armpits and body chemistry are different. To help you figure out if deodorant or antiperspirant is right for you, we spoke with Dendy Engelman, MD, a board-certified dermatologist and Mohs surgeon, to learn how they differ, know what to look for when shopping for each, and get a few recommendations, so you can add some dermatologist-approved picks to your bathroom counter. Experts Featured in This Article Dendy Engelman, MD, is a board-certified dermatologist and Mohs surgeon located in New York City. Antiperspirant vs. Deodorant The main difference between antiperspirant and deodorant is that one prevents sweat while the other masks body odor. Want to dive deeper? Dr. Engelman tells PS that an antiperspirant is a product that "blocks glands that produce sweat in order to prevent or reduce sweating." That's why they're called antiperspirants, because they stop you from perspiring. Whereas "deodorant helps control body odor by making the surface of the skin more acidic and killing and/or preventing the growth of odor-causing bacteria." In recent years, natural deodorants have become quite popular, but unlike antiperspirants, Dr. Engelman explains, they do not prevent sweat. According to Dr. Engelman, most antiperspirants are made with aluminum-based compounds, such as aluminum chlorohydrate (a type of salt complex) and aluminum zirconium tetrachlorohydrate glycine complex (a common active ingredient in personal-care products). If you're looking for an aluminum-free antiperspirant, she explains, these may use ingredients like talc, baking soda, and cornstarch to help prevent sweating. When shopping for deodorants, Engelman says these are typically "alcohol-based and include the bacteria-killing ingredient triclosan, along with odor-binding ingredients (for example, baking soda) and odor-masking perfumes and fragrances." How to Find the Best Deodorant Before you add a new product to your cart, Dr. Engelman advises it may take some trial and error to find the right one. "I recommend looking for a deodorant that is free of aluminum, parabens, added fragrance, and other potentially harmful ingredients - especially if you have sensitive skin," she says. "Labels like natural, fragrance-free, and aluminum-free can help guide you." Dr. Engelman recommends the Tom's of Maine Natural Deodorant Stick ($8) to anyone, as it's a unisex brand with fragrance-free options and all-natural ingredients. "These deodorants are natural, aluminum-free, and produced with sustainable and responsible ingredients," she says. Another great option is the Lume Whole Body Invisible Cream Tube Deodorant ($15), as you can apply it anywhere. "I like the versatility of Lume's Cream Deodorants as the water-based formula makes them easy to apply anywhere bacteria may thrive for whole-body odor protection," she says. "The aluminum- and paraben-free formula is both safe and effective with clinically proven 72-hour odor control." How to Find the Best Antiperspirant If you're worried about sweat and odor, you may want to consider opting for an antiperspirant instead. These will help keep you dry and BO-free. The Secret Clinical Strength Antiperspirant ($13) acts as a long-lasting shield against sweat and odor. "This invisible antiperspirant and deodorant offers 72 hours of protection against stress, heat, and activity sweat in a clinically backed formula," Dr. Engelman says. Another great option is the Degree Clinical Protection 5-in-1 Antiperspirant ($25). Not only does this antiperspirant work to prevent body odor, but it's also dermatologist tested and available at prescription strength. "The five-in-one formula helps reduce sweating, control odor, moisturize the skin, and more," she says. Rylee Johnston is a New York City-based freelance writer who covers everything from beauty, fashion, and celebrity trends to home, pets, and more. With a degree in journalism and over three years of industry experience, she enjoys interviewing experts and testing out products to make the best recommendations for readers.
